content: <div>
Life in Space
<div>
A lot of people ask me what it was like to live in space.
The short answer?
It was...
<div>
The science of it is pretty amazing.
Every astronaut has a unique perspective about living in space.
The fact is the International Space Station orbits the Earth 16 times in a 24 hour period.
It was so cool to watch the sun rise 16 times a day!
<div class='shadow-box'>
I also like to ask people questions to see how much they know about living in space.
Are you ready?
<div>
How long does it take to get to space?
<ul class='list-rocket'>
Use the next button to see if you’re right!
<div>
It takes about nine minutes for the space shuttle to reach Low Earth Orbit (LEO).
Nine minutes I’ll never forget. Hearing the countdown…6…5...4. Feeling the main engines fire up.
The shuttle tilts forward and back—a move we call the “TWANG” at NASA. 3…2…1…0. The solid rocket boosters roar to life…
LIFTOFF!
Imagine accelerating over 100 miles per hour in a sports car. Only it was 100,000 times more intense! As we
approached 17,500 mph, I was pinned to my seat. My chest was tight. I was laboring to breathe. But I was totally excited!
<div>
<figcaption>My first launch aboard the Space Shuttle Atlantis took place in February of 2008. I was privileged to be assigned
to a second mission, STS129, in November of 2009.</figcaption>
<div>
What do you eat?
<ul class='list-rocket'>
Use the next button to see if you’re right!
<div>
Astronauts eat a lot of the same things you eat on Earth, but it’s prepared differently. Food on the space
station has been thermally stabilized and irradiated. People expect it to taste terrible, but it’s actually
pretty good (and we stock lots of condiments like ketchup and hot sauce).
My favorites included beef brisket, mac and cheese, and string beans with almonds. M&M’s and Raisinettes
made great snacks, with the added bonus of being fun to play with. Check out the video to find out why.
<div>
<figcaption>One of my best memories is sharing a meal with all of the space station crew. Breaking bread with people of different races, from all
different places, gives me hope that we can live in unity here on Earth.</figcaption>
<div>
But the best meal I ever had in space wasn’t real. It was a figment of my imagination—a burger, dripping with cheese,
that floated through my dreams. I chomped on that cheeseburger until there was nothing left to chew.
<div>
Where do you sleep?
<ul class='list-rocket'>
Use the next button to see if you’re right!
<div>
In space, you might be sleeping on the ceiling, you just don’t know it! There is no “up” or “down” because you are always able to float to any surface.
The space station is about as big as a house with six rooms so we utilize every available surface for sleeping—the walls, the ceiling and the floor!
Sleeping quarters on the station are really small. Each sleep station is a bit bigger than a sleeping bag, with just enough room for a computer and a few books.
We strap our sleeping bags to the wall with bungees or velcro, zipped them up and floated in place while we slept.
<div>
<figcaption>The velcro straps and zippers kept us from floating away and bumping into equipment and supplies as we slept.</figcaption>
<div>
Why do you have to exercise in space?
<ul class='list-rocket'>
Use the next button to see if you’re right!
<div>
Without gravity, human bones change and lose calcium, becoming more brittle. As a preventive measure, we use bikes
that give us a good cardio workout, as well as treadmills and a Resistive Exercise Device (RED) specially designed to help
us combat the loss of bone density.
The lack of gravity affects bones in other funky ways. For example, every vertebra stretches out a little, elongating
the spine. I’m five foot eleven on Earth but in space I was six feet tall!
<div>
<figcaption>I’m still an avid biker and was really glad to have biking as an exercise option in space!</figcaption>
<div>
What is the coolest thing you see up there?
<ul class='list-rocket'>
Use the next button to see if you’re right!
<div>
I saw so many amazing things from the vantage point of space. There was the green glow from above the southern
hemisphere that flashed like sunbursts—colors exploding unexpectedly right before my eyes. It was crazy and beautiful
and so different from the purple, yellow and blue lights—the aurora borealis—I’d seen in the northern hemisphere.
I took a lot of pictures in space so I would always have those images with me.
But the coolest thing I saw was our home planet, mother Earth, shining out like a beacon in the vastness of space.
It is a sight that changes your perspective forever.
<div>
What happens if you get sick?
<ul class='list-rocket'>
Use the next button to see if you’re right!
<div>
In space, if you get sick, you don’t just send for the doctor! You are treated by one of your crewmates who has been trained
to deal with medical emergencies.
I was the medical officer on my first mission (STS122) and had to learn how to treat illness, stitch up wounds and diagnose
symptoms. For some astronauts, including me, symptoms like nausea and diarrhea feel a lot different in space due to the lack of
gravity – which means there’s not much warning—so we have to be really careful.
I won’t go into detail but just remember—in space EVERYTHING floats!
<div>
What kind of work do you do in space?
<ul class='list-rocket'>
Use the next button to see if you’re right!
This was a bit of a trick question. We do all three! Astronauts are trained to perform multiple duties in space.
I was a mission specialist and operated the robotic arm, installing the Columbus Laboratory onto the
Space Station. With the arm we also help maneuver astronauts around during their spacewalks as they repair
and replace parts on the Space Station.
<div class='img-panel'>
The station is a research facility and all of us help perform experiments and collect data to further our scientific knowledge about the effects of living in space.
<div>
Living in a free fall environment presents a lot of challenges and life in space can be difficult.
There is no water, no oxygen, and you are in a constant state of freefall. Scientists and researchers have
to come up with creative ways to do even the simplest things, like brushing your teeth.
And maintaining the space station is a lot of work. We train for years to be perfect in everything we
do because a mistake could cost someone their life.
Sometimes we get homesick, but we also have fun! I was even lucky enough to get to play football in space.
<div>
<figcaption>Playing football in space</figcaption>
<div class='shadow-box'>
I wouldn’t trade my experience on the International Space Station for anything...
...but life on Earth is pretty good too.
<div class='img-panel'>
<div class='shadow-box'>
Working together we can take care of this planet we call home.
